segment.source: Lab 1: Customize and install Windows using the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)
segment.target: Lab 1: Customize and install Windows using the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)

segment.source: Lab 1: Customize and install Windows using the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)
segment.target: Lab 1: Customize and install Windows using the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)

segment.source: Lab 1: Customize and install Windows using the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)
segment.target: Lab 1: Customize and install Windows using the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD)

segment.source: The fastest way to deploy customized Windows devices is by creating bootable USB keys using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).
segment.target: The fastest way to deploy customized Windows devices is by creating bootable USB keys using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).

segment.source: This tool helps you install device drivers, set system settings, and add languages so you can quickly install Windows onto test or retail devices.
segment.target: This tool helps you install device drivers, set system settings, and add languages so you can quickly install Windows onto test or retail devices.

segment.source: Design your images
segment.target: Design your images

segment.source: Here’s a sample set of hardware configurations that you might design.
segment.target: Here’s a sample set of hardware configurations that you might design.

segment.target: Hardware Configuration:

segment.source: This lab will walk you through hardware configuration 1 with optional steps included for hardware configuration 2.
segment.target: This lab will walk you through hardware configuration 1 with optional steps included for hardware configuration 2.

segment.source: Lab 1b continues the lab to include Classic Windows applications to deploy hardware configuration 1b and 2.
segment.target: Lab 1b continues the lab to include Classic Windows applications to deploy hardware configuration 1b and 2.

segment.source: Lab 1c continues the lab to show you how to edit an expand on existing projects.
segment.target: Lab 1c continues the lab to show you how to edit an expand on existing projects.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a new project in Windows ICD
segment.target: Step 1: Create a new project in Windows ICD

segment.source: Click Start, type icd, and then click Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.
segment.target: Click Start, type icd, and then click Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.

segment.source: If the User Account Control window appears, click Yes.
segment.target: If the User Account Control window appears, click Yes.

segment.source: Click New Windows image customization.
segment.target: Click New Windows image customization.

segment.source: On the Enter project details page, use the following information, and then click Next:
segment.target: On the Enter project details page, use the following information, and then click Next:

segment.source: In the Name box, type FabrikamNotebook1.
segment.target: In the Name box, type FabrikamNotebook1.

segment.source: Leave the Project folder box as-is.
segment.target: Leave the Project folder box as-is.

segment.source: In the Description box, type Base hardware design for the Fabrikam Notebook PC Series 1.
segment.target: In the Description box, type Base hardware design for the Fabrikam Notebook PC Series 1.

segment.source: On the Select imaging source format page, click The Windows image is based on a Windows image (WIM) fileNext.
segment.target: On the Select imaging source format page, click The Windows image is based on a Windows image (WIM) fileNext.

segment.source: On the Select Image page, click Browse.
segment.target: On the Select Image page, click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to C:ImagesWin10x64sources, click install.wim, and then click Open.
segment.target: Browse to C:ImagesWin10x64sources, click install.wim, and then click Open.

segment.source: If working with design 1, select Windows 10 Home.
segment.target: If working with design 1, select Windows 10 Home.

segment.source: If working with design 1b, select Windows 10 Pro.
segment.target: If working with design 1b, select Windows 10 Pro.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the Import a Provisioning Package (Optional) page, if you have a provisioning package (similar to the one you create in Lab 1b), you can add it now, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Import a Provisioning Package (Optional) page, if you have a provisioning package (similar to the one you create in Lab 1b), you can add it now, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Otherwise, you can leave this step blank and click Finish.
segment.target: Otherwise, you can leave this step blank and click Finish.

segment.source: The project is created and the main editing windows appear.
segment.target: The project is created and the main editing windows appear.

segment.source: Troubleshooting: If you get an error while creating the project, make sure you obtained the Windows image from a dedicated download center for OEMs and System Builders.
segment.target: Troubleshooting: If you get an error while creating the project, make sure you obtained the Windows image from a dedicated download center for OEMs and System Builders.

segment.source: The Windows 10 installation media that can be downloaded using the media creation tool cannot be used with Windows Imaging tools.
segment.target: The Windows 10 installation media that can be downloaded using the media creation tool cannot be used with Windows Imaging tools.

segment.source: Step 2: Add the Universal Windows apps and Windows 8.1 apps (Optional)
segment.target: Step 2: Add the Universal Windows apps and Windows 8.1 apps (Optional)

segment.source: You can preload Universal Windows apps to your image so they are available on the PC when your customers start the PC for the first time.
segment.target: You can preload Universal Windows apps to your image so they are available on the PC when your customers start the PC for the first time.

segment.source: With Windows ICD, you add Windows 8.1 apps the same way you add Windows Universal apps to your image.
segment.target: With Windows ICD, you add Windows 8.1 apps the same way you add Windows Universal apps to your image.

segment.source: For hardware configuration 1, you can skip this step if you don’t want to add any apps to your low disk footprint device.
segment.target: For hardware configuration 1, you can skip this step if you don’t want to add any apps to your low disk footprint device.

segment.source: For this walkthrough, we'll add the Office Preview apps (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint).
segment.target: For this walkthrough, we'll add the Office Preview apps (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint).

segment.source: You can repeat these steps for any Universal Windows apps and Windows 8.1 apps you want to add to the image.
segment.target: You can repeat these steps for any Universal Windows apps and Windows 8.1 apps you want to add to the image.

segment.source: In Windows ICD, under Available customizations, expand Deployment assets, and then click Applications.
segment.target: In Windows ICD, under Available customizations, expand Deployment assets, and then click Applications.

segment.source: In the Package path box, click Browse.
segment.target: In the Package path box, click Browse.

segment.source: Change the view to Application Bundle (.appxbundle), select the Word Preview app bundle package, and then click Open.
segment.target: Change the view to Application Bundle (.appxbundle), select the Word Preview app bundle package, and then click Open.

segment.source: In the Name box, type Word Preview.
segment.target: In the Name box, type Word Preview.

segment.source: In the License path box, click Browse.
segment.target: In the License path box, click Browse.

segment.source: Select the Word Preview license file, and then click Open.
segment.target: Select the Word Preview license file, and then click Open.

segment.source: Click Add.
segment.target: Click Add.

segment.source: The app’s name should appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The app’s name should appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: Repeat steps 1 – 5 for the Excel Preview and PowerPoint Preview app bundle packages and any other Universal Windows apps and Windows 8.1 apps you want to add to the image.
segment.target: Repeat steps 1 – 5 for the Excel Preview and PowerPoint Preview app bundle packages and any other Universal Windows apps and Windows 8.1 apps you want to add to the image.

segment.source: OneNote and Reader 8.1 apps are included on the event-provided USB.
segment.target: OneNote and Reader 8.1 apps are included on the event-provided USB.

segment.source: Step 3: Add a driver to the image
segment.target: Step 3: Add a driver to the image

segment.source: You can use Windows ICD to add your own INF-based driver to your image.
segment.target: You can use Windows ICD to add your own INF-based driver to your image.

segment.source: In Windows ICD, under Available Customizations, expand Deployment assets, and then click Drivers.
segment.target: In Windows ICD, under Available Customizations, expand Deployment assets, and then click Drivers.

segment.source: In the middle pane, next to Driver folder path, click Browse.
segment.target: In the middle pane, next to Driver folder path, click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to your INF-based driver, and then click OK.
segment.target: Browse to your INF-based driver, and then click OK.

segment.source: The driver .inf file should show up in the Drivers box.
segment.target: The driver .inf file should show up in the Drivers box.

segment.source: If there are multiple drivers in that folder, all of the drivers in that folder will be added.
segment.target: If there are multiple drivers in that folder, all of the drivers in that folder will be added.

segment.source: Note Some drivers are packaged as .zip or .exe files.
segment.target: Note Some drivers are packaged as .zip or .exe files.

segment.source: You'll need to unzip or extract these files before adding them.
segment.target: You'll need to unzip or extract these files before adding them.

segment.source: Some driver files, like the sample driver given, include files for both x86 and x64 devices, this is OK.
segment.target: Some driver files, like the sample driver given, include files for both x86 and x64 devices, this is OK.

segment.source: In the Name box, type Fabrikam Video Card 100.
segment.target: In the Name box, type Fabrikam Video Card 100.

segment.source: If you're testing new device designs with prototype or pre-release drivers from your hardware manufacturer, select the Force unsigned install check box, then click Add.
segment.target: If you're testing new device designs with prototype or pre-release drivers from your hardware manufacturer, select the Force unsigned install check box, then click Add.

segment.source: The driver's descriptive name should appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The driver's descriptive name should appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: Step 4: Add some customized settings to the image
segment.target: Step 4: Add some customized settings to the image

segment.source: In Windows ICD, in the Available Customizations pane, expand Image time settings, and then click OEM.
segment.target: In Windows ICD, in the Available Customizations pane, expand Image time settings, and then click OEM.

segment.source: In the middle pane, in the Name box, type Fabrikam.
segment.target: In the middle pane, in the Name box, type Fabrikam.

segment.source: In the Available Customizations pane, under OEM, click Information.
segment.target: In the Available Customizations pane, under OEM, click Information.

segment.source: Fill in the following information:
segment.target: Fill in the following information:

segment.source: In the Manufacturer box, type Fabrikam.
segment.target: In the Manufacturer box, type Fabrikam.

segment.source: In the SupportHours box, type 8 AM - 5 PM.
segment.target: In the SupportHours box, type 8 AM - 5 PM.

segment.source: In the SupportPhone box, type 555-1212.
segment.target: In the SupportPhone box, type 555-1212.

segment.source: In the SupportURL box, type http://support.fabrikam.com.
segment.target: In the SupportURL box, type http://support.fabrikam.com.

segment.source: The settings appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The settings appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: Step 5: Customize the Start layout
segment.target: Step 5: Customize the Start layout

segment.source: In Windows 10, OEMs can modify the default Start layout and specify the layout of the OEM tiles by creating a LayoutModification.xml file and placing this file in the correct system location.
segment.target: In Windows 10, OEMs can modify the default Start layout and specify the layout of the OEM tiles by creating a LayoutModification.xml file and placing this file in the correct system location.

segment.source: Create a layoutmodification.xml file.
segment.target: Create a layoutmodification.xml file.

segment.source: For this lab, you can use the sample on the USB.
segment.target: For this lab, you can use the sample on the USB.

segment.source: The sample will pin Office, OneNote and Reader 8.1 to Start if they have been preloaded on the device (Step 2).
segment.target: The sample will pin Office, OneNote and Reader 8.1 to Start if they have been preloaded on the device (Step 2).

segment.source: To create your own layoutmodification.xml file by using an XML editor, see the Sample scripts.
segment.target: To create your own layoutmodification.xml file by using an XML editor, see the Sample scripts.

segment.source: In Windows ICD, in the Available customizations pane, expand Runtime settings, click Start, and then click StartLayout.
segment.target: In Windows ICD, in the Available customizations pane, expand Runtime settings, click Start, and then click StartLayout.

segment.source: In the middle pane, click Browse.
segment.target: In the middle pane, click Browse.

segment.source: Navigate to the location where you saved the LayoutModification.xml file.
segment.target: Navigate to the location where you saved the LayoutModification.xml file.

segment.source: Select the file, and then click Open.
segment.target: Select the file, and then click Open.

segment.source: This should set the value of StartLayout.
segment.target: This should set the value of StartLayout.

segment.source: The setting appears in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The setting appears in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: Note You cannot add .url and .lnk files directly in Windows ICD.
segment.target: Note You cannot add .url and .lnk files directly in Windows ICD.

segment.source: If you have these files, follow Step 2 in lab 2 in the section ”Add the files you need to modify the Start layout”.
segment.target: If you have these files, follow Step 2 in lab 2 in the section ”Add the files you need to modify the Start layout”.

segment.source: Step 6: Add a language
segment.target: Step 6: Add a language

segment.source: Windows ICD provides a basic method of adding languages.
segment.target: Windows ICD provides a basic method of adding languages.

segment.source: In Windows ICD, in the Available customizations pane, expand Deployment assets, and then click Language packages.
segment.target: In Windows ICD, in the Available customizations pane, expand Deployment assets, and then click Language packages.

segment.source: In the middle pane, next to Cab file, click Browse.
segment.target: In the middle pane, next to Cab file, click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to the language pack file, for example: C:SamplesLanguagesfr-fr x64-client, click lp.cab, and then click Open.
segment.target: Browse to the language pack file, for example: C:SamplesLanguagesfr-fr x64-client, click lp.cab, and then click Open.

segment.source: In the Name box, type French user interface, and then click Add.
segment.target: In the Name box, type French user interface, and then click Add.

segment.source: The language pack should appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The language pack should appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: This method also does not update the language resources for Windows applications.
segment.target: This method also does not update the language resources for Windows applications.

segment.source: Including the Windows inbox apps.
segment.target: Including the Windows inbox apps.

segment.source: While some Windows apps will be updated automatically through Windows Update, others may need to be reinstalled later.
segment.target: While some Windows apps will be updated automatically through Windows Update, others may need to be reinstalled later.

segment.source: To update the resources for Windows RE and for apps, modify the Windows install.wim image, using the instructions from Lab 2: Classic-style deployment.
segment.target: To update the resources for Windows RE and for apps, modify the Windows install.wim image, using the instructions from Lab 2: Classic-style deployment.

segment.source: You can skip steps 4 and 5 (adding windows drivers and modifying the Start layout), and you can skip optional steps 11 and 12 (upgrading the Windows edition and setting the image to boot to audit mode).
segment.target: You can skip steps 4 and 5 (adding windows drivers and modifying the Start layout), and you can skip optional steps 11 and 12 (upgrading the Windows edition and setting the image to boot to audit mode).

segment.source: Step 7: Add features on demand
segment.target: Step 7: Add features on demand

segment.source: Features on demand (FODs) are Windows feature packages that can be added at any time.
segment.target: Features on demand (FODs) are Windows feature packages that can be added at any time.

segment.source: When a user needs a new feature, they can request the feature package from Windows Update.
segment.target: When a user needs a new feature, they can request the feature package from Windows Update.

segment.source: OEMs can preinstall these features to enable them on their devices out of the box.
segment.target: OEMs can preinstall these features to enable them on their devices out of the box.

segment.source: Common features include language resources like handwriting recognition.
segment.target: Common features include language resources like handwriting recognition.

segment.source: Some of these features are required to enable full Cortana functionality.
segment.target: Some of these features are required to enable full Cortana functionality.

segment.source: The following table shows the types of language components available for Windows and which ones apply to Cortana.
segment.target: The following table shows the types of language components available for Windows and which ones apply to Cortana.

segment.source: In addition, to enable Cortana or for pen support, features need to be added in a specific order.
segment.target: In addition, to enable Cortana or for pen support, features need to be added in a specific order.

segment.source: For example, to enable Cortana, install these features in this order: lp.cab, then Basic, then TextToSpeech, then Speech.
segment.target: For example, to enable Cortana, install these features in this order: lp.cab, then Basic, then TextToSpeech, then Speech.

segment.source: To enable pen support, install these features in this order: lp.cab, then Basic, then Handwriting.
segment.target: To enable pen support, install these features in this order: lp.cab, then Basic, then Handwriting.

segment.source: Component
segment.target: Component

segment.source: Sample file name
segment.target: Sample file name

segment.source: Dependencies
segment.target: Dependencies

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Language pack
segment.target: Language pack

segment.source: None
segment.target: None

segment.source: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.
segment.target: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.

segment.source: Language interface pack
segment.target: Language interface pack

segment.source: Requires a specific fully-localized or partially-localized language pack.
segment.target: Requires a specific fully-localized or partially-localized language pack.

segment.source: Example: ca-ES requires es-ES.
segment.target: Example: ca-ES requires es-ES.

segment.source: To learn more, see Available Language Packs for Windows.
segment.target: To learn more, see Available Language Packs for Windows.

segment.source: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.
segment.target: UI text, including basic Cortana capabilities.

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: None
segment.target: None

segment.source: Spell checking, text prediction, word breaking, and hyphenation if available for the language.
segment.target: Spell checking, text prediction, word breaking, and hyphenation if available for the language.

segment.source: You must add this component before adding any of the following components.
segment.target: You must add this component before adding any of the following components.

segment.source: Fonts
segment.target: Fonts

segment.source: None
segment.target: None

segment.source: Fonts.
segment.target: Fonts.

segment.source: Required for some regions to render text that appears in documents.
segment.target: Required for some regions to render text that appears in documents.

segment.source: Example, th-TH requires the Thai font pack.
segment.target: Example, th-TH requires the Thai font pack.

segment.source: To learn more, see Features On Demand V2 (Capabilities).
segment.target: To learn more, see Features On Demand V2 (Capabilities).

segment.source: Optical character recognition
segment.target: Optical character recognition

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: Recognizes and outputs text in an image.
segment.target: Recognizes and outputs text in an image.

segment.source: Handwriting recognition
segment.target: Handwriting recognition

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: Enables handwriting recognition for devices with pen input.
segment.target: Enables handwriting recognition for devices with pen input.

segment.source: Text-to-speech
segment.target: Text-to-speech

segment.source: Basic
segment.target: Basic

segment.source: Enables text to speech, used by Cortana and Narrator.
segment.target: Enables text to speech, used by Cortana and Narrator.

segment.source: Speech recognition
segment.target: Speech recognition

segment.source: Basic, Text-To-Speech recognition
segment.target: Basic, Text-To-Speech recognition

segment.source: Recognizes voice input, used by Cortana and Windows Speech Recognition.
segment.target: Recognizes voice input, used by Cortana and Windows Speech Recognition.

segment.source: In Windows ICD, in the Available customizations pane, expand Deployment assets, and then click Features on demand.
segment.target: In Windows ICD, in the Available customizations pane, expand Deployment assets, and then click Features on demand.

segment.source: In the middle pane, next to Features package path, click Browse.
segment.target: In the middle pane, next to Features package path, click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to the FOD file, for example: C:SamplesLanguagesfr-fr x64-client, click Microsoft-Windows-LanguageFeatures-Basic-fr-fr-Package.cab, and then click Open.
segment.target: Browse to the FOD file, for example: C:SamplesLanguagesfr-fr x64-client, click Microsoft-Windows-LanguageFeatures-Basic-fr-fr-Package.cab, and then click Open.

segment.source: In the Name box, type French basic language component, and then click Add.
segment.target: In the Name box, type French basic language component, and then click Add.

segment.source: The language component should appear in the Configured customizations pane.
segment.target: The language component should appear in the Configured customizations pane.

segment.source: In the middle pane, next to Cab File, click Browse.
segment.target: In the middle pane, next to Cab File, click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to the FOD file, for example: C:SamplesLanguagesfr-fr x64-client, click Microsoft-Windows-LanguageFeatures-Speech-fr-fr-Package.cab, and then click Open.
segment.target: Browse to the FOD file, for example: C:SamplesLanguagesfr-fr x64-client, click Microsoft-Windows-LanguageFeatures-Speech-fr-fr-Package.cab, and then click Open.

segment.source: In the Name box, type French speech language component, and then click Add.
segment.target: In the Name box, type French speech language component, and then click Add.

segment.source: The language components should appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The language components should appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: Repeat the steps to add the Text-to-Speech and Speech components.
segment.target: Repeat the steps to add the Text-to-Speech and Speech components.

segment.source: The language components should appear in the Selected customizations pane.
segment.target: The language components should appear in the Selected customizations pane.

segment.source: For languages that require fonts, such as Chinese (Simplified), add the font pack.
segment.target: For languages that require fonts, such as Chinese (Simplified), add the font pack.

segment.source: To learn which languages require fonts, see Features On Demand V2 (Capabilities).
segment.target: To learn which languages require fonts, see Features On Demand V2 (Capabilities).

segment.source: In the middle pane, next to Cab File, click Browse.
segment.target: In the middle pane, next to Cab File, click Browse.

segment.source: Browse to the FOD file, for example: C:SamplesLanguageszh-cn x64-client, click Microsoft-Windows-LanguageFeatures-Fonts-Hans-Package.cab, and then click Open.
segment.target: Browse to the FOD file, for example: C:SamplesLanguageszh-cn x64-client, click Microsoft-Windows-LanguageFeatures-Fonts-Hans-Package.cab, and then click Open.

segment.source: In the Name box, type Chinese (simplified) font language component, and then click Add.
segment.target: In the Name box, type Chinese (simplified) font language component, and then click Add.

segment.source: The language components should appear in the Configured customizations pane.
segment.target: The language components should appear in the Configured customizations pane.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can’t update the language in the Windows Recovery Environment from Windows ICD.
segment.target: You can’t update the language in the Windows Recovery Environment from Windows ICD.

segment.source: By default, if there's a problem, the device will show recovery screens in English only.
segment.target: By default, if there's a problem, the device will show recovery screens in English only.

segment.source: You run Dism.exe (or a script) to remove English after you add another language.
segment.target: You run Dism.exe (or a script) to remove English after you add another language.

segment.source: For an example, see Lab 2: Classic-style deployment, step 7.
segment.target: For an example, see Lab 2: Classic-style deployment, step 7.

segment.source: After adding a language, you'll need to re-add the Universal apps (APPX).
segment.target: After adding a language, you'll need to re-add the Universal apps (APPX).

segment.source: This process needs to be performed during Audit mode.
segment.target: This process needs to be performed during Audit mode.

segment.source: For more information on how to remove and re-add these applications, please refer to Lab 2: Classic-style deployment, step 8.
segment.target: For more information on how to remove and re-add these applications, please refer to Lab 2: Classic-style deployment, step 8.

segment.source: In Windows 10 builds after August 18, 2015, you can now add new Universal apps (APPX) on top of the existing ones.
segment.target: In Windows 10 builds after August 18, 2015, you can now add new Universal apps (APPX) on top of the existing ones.

segment.source: It is no longer necessary to remove the prior versions before re-adding them.
segment.target: It is no longer necessary to remove the prior versions before re-adding them.

segment.source: Step 8: Save the image
segment.target: Step 8: Save the image

segment.source: Windows ICD can store the entire image into a single .FFU file.
segment.target: Windows ICD can store the entire image into a single .FFU file.

segment.source: The FFU format was developed for faster, safer deployment by using sector-based imaging and security headers.
segment.target: The FFU format was developed for faster, safer deployment by using sector-based imaging and security headers.

segment.source: Click CreateProduction media.
segment.target: Click CreateProduction media.

segment.source: Select FFUNext.
segment.target: Select FFUNext.

segment.source: For hardware designs 1 and 1b, select Yes under Enable Compact OS, and then click Next.
segment.target: For hardware designs 1 and 1b, select Yes under Enable Compact OS, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Configure Audit Mode Boot, leave all options by default, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Configure Audit Mode Boot, leave all options by default, and then click Next.

segment.source: In Choose where the FFU file is saved, give the file a name, such as C:ImagesMyFFUImage.ffu, and then click Next.
segment.target: In Choose where the FFU file is saved, give the file a name, such as C:ImagesMyFFUImage.ffu, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note We recommend choosing a location on a hard drive rather than a USB key, as it can make the FFU creation process faster.
segment.target: Note We recommend choosing a location on a hard drive rather than a USB key, as it can make the FFU creation process faster.

segment.source: Review the settings and ensure they are correct.
segment.target: Review the settings and ensure they are correct.

segment.source: Click Build.
segment.target: Click Build.

segment.source: Windows ICD creates the FFU file using the name and path indicated in the previous step.
segment.target: Windows ICD creates the FFU file using the name and path indicated in the previous step.

segment.source: This will take a few minutes.
segment.target: This will take a few minutes.

segment.source: Click Finish.
segment.target: Click Finish.

segment.source: Troubleshooting: If the project fails to build:
segment.target: Troubleshooting: If the project fails to build:

segment.source: Check to make sure there's no leading or trailing spaces in the project name.
segment.target: Check to make sure there's no leading or trailing spaces in the project name.

segment.source: If there is, recreate the project.
segment.target: If there is, recreate the project.

segment.source: The requested operation couldn't be completed due to a file size limitation: Check to see that the drive is formatted using the NTFS file format and has at least 5GB free.
segment.target: The requested operation couldn't be completed due to a file size limitation: Check to see that the drive is formatted using the NTFS file format and has at least 5GB free.

segment.source: If at any time you end up repeating this walkthrough, if you want to use the same project, delete the existing project folder from DocumentsWindows Imaging and Configuration Designer (WICD) before starting again.
segment.target: If at any time you end up repeating this walkthrough, if you want to use the same project, delete the existing project folder from DocumentsWindows Imaging and Configuration Designer (WICD) before starting again.

segment.source: Copy the FFU file to a removable storage device, like a separate USB key or an external USB drive.
segment.target: Copy the FFU file to a removable storage device, like a separate USB key or an external USB drive.

segment.source: You may need to reformat the drive using the NTFS format so that it can accept very large files - depending on how many languages, drivers, and apps you add, the .FFU file can easily be 5GB or larger.
segment.target: You may need to reformat the drive using the NTFS format so that it can accept very large files - depending on how many languages, drivers, and apps you add, the .FFU file can easily be 5GB or larger.

segment.source: You probably won't be able to use the Windows PE key for this - it's formatted using FAT32, which only accepts files that are 4GB or smaller.
segment.target: You probably won't be able to use the Windows PE key for this - it's formatted using FAT32, which only accepts files that are 4GB or smaller.

segment.source: Step 9: Install Windows on the reference device
segment.target: Step 9: Install Windows on the reference device

segment.source: Insert the WinPE USB drive into your reference device.
segment.target: Insert the WinPE USB drive into your reference device.

segment.source: Boot up the reference device to the boot device selection menu.
segment.target: Boot up the reference device to the boot device selection menu.

segment.source: You usually do this by powering on the device and quickly pressing a specific key or button (for example, the Esc key or the Volume down button), and selecting the USB key.
segment.target: You usually do this by powering on the device and quickly pressing a specific key or button (for example, the Esc key or the Volume down button), and selecting the USB key.

segment.source: Insert the FFU USB drive into your reference device.
segment.target: Insert the FFU USB drive into your reference device.

segment.source: Determine which driver letter is assigned to this drive by doing the following:
segment.target: Determine which driver letter is assigned to this drive by doing the following:

segment.source: From the WinPE command prompt, type: diskpart and press Enter.
segment.target: From the WinPE command prompt, type: diskpart and press Enter.

segment.source: At the diskpart prompt, typelist volume and press Enter.
segment.target: At the diskpart prompt, typelist volume and press Enter.

segment.source: This lists all of the volumes present in the system.
segment.target: This lists all of the volumes present in the system.

segment.source: Determine the driver letter that corresponds to the FFU USB key, for example, G.
segment.target: Determine the driver letter that corresponds to the FFU USB key, for example, G.

segment.source: From the WinPE command prompt, type the following:
segment.target: From the WinPE command prompt, type the following:

segment.source: Where G:MyFFUImage.ffu is the file location of the FFU file.
segment.target: Where G:MyFFUImage.ffu is the file location of the FFU file.

segment.source: Repeat Step 9: Use your new Windows installation key to set up more devices.
segment.target: Repeat Step 9: Use your new Windows installation key to set up more devices.

segment.source: At the Get going fast screen, turn off the device by pressing and holding the power button.
segment.target: At the Get going fast screen, turn off the device by pressing and holding the power button.

segment.source: Do not complete the OOBE for your customer.
segment.target: Do not complete the OOBE for your customer.

segment.source: There's a known bug where if your PC is set to automatically boot to a USB key, it will get caught in a loop during the install process: after Windows installs, it reinstalls again and again.
segment.target: There's a known bug where if your PC is set to automatically boot to a USB key, it will get caught in a loop during the install process: after Windows installs, it reinstalls again and again.

segment.source: To avoid this loop:
segment.target: To avoid this loop:

segment.source: Workaround: Prepare the reference device
segment.target: Workaround: Prepare the reference device

segment.source: On your reference device, open the device's boot menus.
segment.target: On your reference device, open the device's boot menus.

segment.source: You usually do this by powering on the device and quickly pressing a specific key or button (for example, the Esc key or the Volume up button).
segment.target: You usually do this by powering on the device and quickly pressing a specific key or button (for example, the Esc key or the Volume up button).

segment.source: Find the boot order menu (this menu has different names and locations) and make sure that the hard drive is set up to be first in the boot sequence, not the USB drive.
segment.target: Find the boot order menu (this menu has different names and locations) and make sure that the hard drive is set up to be first in the boot sequence, not the USB drive.

segment.source: If your device doesn't appear to have a way to change the boot order on during the boot sequence, the option may be disabled.
segment.target: If your device doesn't appear to have a way to change the boot order on during the boot sequence, the option may be disabled.

segment.source: Look for a option like "Enable Boot Options on Startup" or "F12 Boot Menu", and enable the menu.
segment.target: Look for a option like "Enable Boot Options on Startup" or "F12 Boot Menu", and enable the menu.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: If Windows doesn't install on the reference device, try each of these steps:
segment.target: If Windows doesn't install on the reference device, try each of these steps:

segment.source: USB key doesn't appear in the boot menus: Try using different USB ports on the computer.
segment.target: USB key doesn't appear in the boot menus: Try using different USB ports on the computer.

segment.source: Avoid using USB hubs or cables.
segment.target: Avoid using USB hubs or cables.

segment.source: Restart the PC and open the device's boot menus.
segment.target: Restart the PC and open the device's boot menus.

segment.source: Look for an option to enable a boot device selection menu on startup (example: "F12 Boot menu").
segment.target: Look for an option to enable a boot device selection menu on startup (example: "F12 Boot menu").

segment.source: If you find one, enable it!
segment.target: If you find one, enable it!

segment.source: UEFI or BIOS: If your boot menus give you a choice between booting in UEFI mode or BIOS mode, choose UEFI mode.
segment.target: UEFI or BIOS: If your boot menus give you a choice between booting in UEFI mode or BIOS mode, choose UEFI mode.

segment.source: If the device boots up to the Drive Selection menu, select the primary hard drive, this is usually the C drive.
segment.target: If the device boots up to the Drive Selection menu, select the primary hard drive, this is usually the C drive.

segment.source: If you're not sure which drive is which, press Shift-F10 to open the Command Prompt.
segment.target: If you're not sure which drive is which, press Shift-F10 to open the Command Prompt.

segment.source: Type diskpart and press Enter.
segment.target: Type diskpart and press Enter.

segment.source: At the Diskpart prompt, type list volume to show the partitions.
segment.target: At the Diskpart prompt, type list volume to show the partitions.

segment.source: Type exit.
segment.target: Type exit.

segment.source: Press Alt-Tab to try again.
segment.target: Press Alt-Tab to try again.

segment.source: If the device gets through 6% of the installation and then fails, you may need to prepare the drive:
segment.target: If the device gets through 6% of the installation and then fails, you may need to prepare the drive:

segment.source: Plug the USB key.
segment.target: Plug the USB key.

segment.source: Select Troubleshoot Advanced Options Command Prompt.
segment.target: Select Troubleshoot Advanced Options Command Prompt.

segment.source: Type diskpart and press Enter.
segment.target: Type diskpart and press Enter.

segment.source: At the Diskpart prompt, type list volume to list the drives.
segment.target: At the Diskpart prompt, type list volume to list the drives.

segment.source: Type exit to leave the Diskpart prompt.
segment.target: Type exit to leave the Diskpart prompt.

segment.source: Type diskpart /s D:SamplesCreatePartitions-UEFI.txt
segment.target: Type diskpart /s D:SamplesCreatePartitions-UEFI.txt

segment.source: where D is the drive letter of the USB key.
segment.target: where D is the drive letter of the USB key.

segment.source: For BIOS-based PCs, use CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt instead.
segment.target: For BIOS-based PCs, use CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt instead.

segment.source: Type exit to leave the Command prompt.
segment.target: Type exit to leave the Command prompt.

segment.source: Select Turn off your PC.
segment.target: Select Turn off your PC.

segment.source: Turn on the device and open the boot device selection.
segment.target: Turn on the device and open the boot device selection.

segment.source: If you have a choice between booting in BIOS or UEFI mode, select UEFI mode.
segment.target: If you have a choice between booting in BIOS or UEFI mode, select UEFI mode.

segment.source: Windows ICD should install correctly.
segment.target: Windows ICD should install correctly.

segment.source: If the device boots up to the Choose an option: Troubleshoot / Turn off your PC menu, you may be seeing a known bug with USB 3.0 and Windows ICD images.
segment.target: If the device boots up to the Choose an option: Troubleshoot / Turn off your PC menu, you may be seeing a known bug with USB 3.0 and Windows ICD images.

segment.source: Try again using a USB 2.0 key or port.
segment.target: Try again using a USB 2.0 key or port.

segment.source: Make sure your device and the Windows image match.
segment.target: Make sure your device and the Windows image match.

segment.source: If they don't match, try creating the image again using the correct architecture.
segment.target: If they don't match, try creating the image again using the correct architecture.

segment.source: Test the customizations
segment.target: Test the customizations

segment.source: Do these steps to test an image.
segment.target: Do these steps to test an image.

segment.source: Note, this requires completing the First User Experience and creating a user account.
segment.target: Note, this requires completing the First User Experience and creating a user account.

segment.source: After performing these steps, you'd typically need to reinstall Windows onto the device before sending it to a customer.
segment.target: After performing these steps, you'd typically need to reinstall Windows onto the device before sending it to a customer.

segment.source: Make sure the device is not plugged into the network, and turn it on.
segment.target: Make sure the device is not plugged into the network, and turn it on.

segment.source: After the device boots, if the Languages screen appears and shows the French language, then the language pack has been added correctly.
segment.target: After the device boots, if the Languages screen appears and shows the French language, then the language pack has been added correctly.

segment.source: Choose the language you're most familiar with, choose your keyboard, and then click Next.
segment.target: Choose the language you're most familiar with, choose your keyboard, and then click Next.

segment.source: Complete the Out of Box Experience (OOBE): these steps may vary based on language.
segment.target: Complete the Out of Box Experience (OOBE): these steps may vary based on language.

segment.source: On the Hi there screen, click Accept.
segment.target: On the Hi there screen, click Accept.

segment.source: If it asks you for a product key, click Do this later.
segment.target: If it asks you for a product key, click Do this later.

segment.source: If you're plugged into a network connection, you may be asked to provide a product key.
segment.target: If you're plugged into a network connection, you may be asked to provide a product key.

segment.source: To avoid using a product key, disconnect the device and try again.
segment.target: To avoid using a product key, disconnect the device and try again.

segment.source: Click Accept , click Skip this step, and then click Use express settings.
segment.target: Click Accept , click Skip this step, and then click Use express settings.

segment.source: On the Who owns this PC? page, click I do, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Who owns this PC? page, click I do, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Make it yours page, click Skip this step.
segment.target: On the Make it yours page, click Skip this step.

segment.source: Add a user name (example: "Terry"), and then click Next.
segment.target: Add a user name (example: "Terry"), and then click Next.

segment.source: The device finalizes setup and reboots to the desktop.
segment.target: The device finalizes setup and reboots to the desktop.

segment.source: When the desktop appears, in Settings under System About, you should see the technical support info that you entered earlier appear (company name, support phone number, and support website).
segment.target: When the desktop appears, in Settings under System About, you should see the technical support info that you entered earlier appear (company name, support phone number, and support website).
